text: English pronunciation lesson 12 topic
omission of the consonant sound
T
well as you can see we've had a very big
snowfall here in New England but that's
fine by me
because I really enjoy a white Christmas
and Christmas is only two days away you
know Christmas is one of those words in
English that is written with the T but
we don't pronounce it
now many viewers have asked me about the
pronunciation of T in American English
and I hope to make that lesson in the
future but for now what I'd like to do
is explain when the T is not pronounced
I'm going to explain four cases in which
we don't say the T usually and hopefully
this will help you better understand
American English when it's spoken group
one in some words we always omit or
leave out the T for example Christmas
never say Crist
myths only Christmas now here's a list
of words in which a T sound is left out
note that this list is not complete
listen as I say the words bustled
Christmas hustle mistletoe whistle
wrestle now bustle and hustle are
similar words and they refer to busy
noisy activity kind of like the holiday
shopping you see in stores mistletoe is
a kind of plant with a white berry and
there's a Christmas tradition that if
two people are caught under the
mistletoe they have to kiss whistle as
you know is a sound that's me whistling
and rustle means to struggle or fight
with let me say the words again and you
repeat after me bustle
Christmas hustle mistletoe whistle
wrestle text1 listen as I read the text
I love the hustle and bustle of
Christmas even while I wrestle with
shopping bags
I want to whistle a merry holiday tune
and I'm never too busy to share a sweet
kiss under the mistletoe now I'll read
the text again I'll pause after each
sentence and I want you to repeat after
me
I loved the hustle and bustle of
Christmas even while I wrestle with
shopping bags
I want to whistle a merry holiday tune
and I'm never too busy to share a sweet
kiss under the mistletoe group 2 in fast
informal speech we sometimes omit the T
in the prefix inter as in international
so in careful speech we say
international but in fast and formal
speech you may hear international here's
a list of words that all share the same
prefix enter I'll first read the word
with careful pronunciation you will hear
the pronunciation of T then I'll repeat
the word with fast informal
pronunciation you will not hear the T
listen carefully and try to repeat
interactive interactive intermediate
intermediate international international
internet internet texts to listen as I
read the text
I will not read slowly and carefully I
will be reading fast so that you will
hear the omission of the consonant sound
T the T's that are underlined are the
t's that are omitted English is truly an
international language it's easier now
than ever to learn English whether
you're a beginner intermediate or
advanced student the Internet offers
language videos and lots of interactive
exercises if you'd like to go back you
may use your pause key to pause and
repeat after me but this is mainly an
exercise in listening I'd like you to
understand the spoken English group 3 in
fast and formal speech we sometimes omit
the T in a consonant group at the end of
a word now by consonant group I mean
three consonant sounds or more for
example the word X we have three
consonant sounds
these are voiceless sounds and we drop
the middle one which happens to be a T
instead of ax we say X here's a group of
five common words in English they all
end with a consonant group that even for
native speakers is difficult to
pronounce that's why in fast speech we
leave out the T sound listen closely and
try to repeat after me accepts ax lifts
rests tests in the final two words you
need to lengthen the S sound make it
long so that people can understand the
word you're saying
rests tests text 3 listen as I read the
text I will not be reading at a slow
rate I will read fast so that the
omission of the T sounds natural
grandpa accepts help from no one
it's sad he lives heavy things and acts
like it's easy but the weight test his
strength he rests when he thinks no one
is looking I keep telling him to let me
help one day
maybe he'll listen note that listen is
one of those words in which we always
omit the T sound now if you'd like to go
back you can use your pause button to
repeat after me but again this is
another text in which I feel it's more
important to understand rather than
repeat
group 4 in fast and formal speech we
sometimes amid the tea when the ending
of one word in the beginning of another
form a consonant group for example she
kept shopping now in careful speech you
would hear the tea she kept shopping but
in fast and formal speech we dropped the
T in that consonant group the consonant
group is but she kept shopping read and
then answer the questions first all
state the question you can repeat after
me and then you can state your answer
number one let's drop the T in the
consonant group Joo what's the worst
joke you've heard
number two we're going to drop the T
sound in the consonant group which
animals make the best pets 3 we're going
to drop the T sound in the consonant
group to do what's the worst job in the
